block.p: DEAR DIARY:

While visiting Las Vegas last week, we went to see the new Venetian Hotel. Walking in its reproduction of St. Mark's Square in front of the Doge's Palace, I said to my wife, ''The only things missing are the pigeons.''
With that, the man next to us -- who did not know us or where we lived -- turned to me and said: ''I just saw a couple of pigeons. They looked like they came from New Jersey.''

While a ''Florio Free'' bumper sticker delivers a distinct political opinion in New Jersey, its meaning gets muddled once the attached car crosses state borders.
A Delaware resident, reading the message, asked, ''Is Florio one of those chemicals that's depleting the ozone layer?''
DOROTHY FISCHER

While waiting for my husband to select shrubs at a nursery in Hillsdale, I saw a little girl about 4 or 5 standing alone. I asked her what her name was but she refused to tell me. I said that if she told me her name, I would tell her mine.
''I know your name,'' she said. ''It's Grandma.''
BELLE G. KESSELMAN
We were at one of our favorite restaurants in West Orange with some friends recently when one of them said, ''Remember when you didn't have a waitperson,''
''Or,'' another said, ''even know what a waitperson was. How about when they keep asking if you guys are doing O.K.''
I said, ''The best one we had was in Hawaii. A young guy in a flowered shirt handed us each a chilled fork and said, 'I'm Wayne, your salad person.' ''
Was that posh service or what?
DORIS L. MEYER
Scene: The kitchen table:
Child No. 1: ''You know that book that starts, 'Call me E-mail?' ''
Husband and I (laughing): 'You mean, ''Call me Ishmael.' ''
Child No 1: ''Yeah.''
Husband: ''Do you know what book that is?''
Child No 1: ''I know. The book about whales.''
Child No 2: ''Free Willy?''
DEBRA GALANT
I guess anybody going to see ''Austin Powers'' shouldn't really be looking for a genteel crowd.

At a theater in Nutley the other night, an altercation broke out between a row of teen-agers and a mom. Finally, the usher came to the mother's aid, after which a middle-aged woman turned around to admonish the teen-agers.
''Is this how your mothers taught you to act?'' the woman asked.
''No,'' was the response. ''But our mothers aren't here.''
The old saying goes, ''When three different people tell you or suggest to you a different way to do something, it is time to listen.''
Or, ''Things happen in threes.''
For me, it was driving the roads of New Jersey recently and having to fill my car with gas. I stopped at three different Shell stations and had bad experiences at all three.
When I mentioned this to a friend from Long Island, she commented, ''It seems the only good shells to be found in New Jersey may be at the shore.''
LAURA COBRINIK
Infringing on our liberties, the State
Would ban nude bathing at Higbee Beach. But wait!
Where will they go, those poor unfortunates
Who cannot find a bathing suit that fits?
BOB McKENTY
Overheard on the steps leading to the beach at the Spring Lake boardwalk on Memorial Day weekend:
Mother to young son (about 3 or 4 years old): ''No, Joey, tie-dyed is not the same thing as high tide.''
PAT DURKIN-WIGNALL
